block.para: In \RNr[2] and in \RNr[3] we illustrate what we mean by ‘distance of a point from a hyperplalne’.
In \RNr[2] a hyperplane is a line. So we will develop a formula which computes the distance of a point Q in \RNr[2] from a line L in \RNr[2].

info.para: Connections from Q to points on L have varying lengths. So what shall we mean by ‘distance of Q from L?

block.para: Given a line L in \RNr[2] and a point Q, there is always exactly one point R on L which is closest to Q. So we define the distance from Q to L to be the distance from Q to R.
In \RNr[3] a hyperplane is a plane in the conversational sense. So we will develop a formula which computes the distance of a point Q in \RNr[3] from a plane L in \RNr[3].

info.para: The point R is the point on the plane closest to Q.

block.para: Given a plane \Pi in \RNr[2] and a point Q, there is always exactly one point R on \Pi whose distance from R is less than the distance of any other point on \Pi from Q. Thus we define the distance from Q to \Pi to be the distance from Q to the point on \Pi closest to Q.
